articles.headline: Risky Business for C.E.O.s: An Invitation From Trump
articles.snippet: A summons to the White House has long been much coveted. But for some top executives, it has become something to be ducked, lest it make them a target.
articles.abstract: A summons to the White House has long been much coveted. But for some top executives, it has become something to be ducked, lest it make them a target.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the nation’s top executives, a summons to the White House has long been a much-coveted honor.

articles.headline: ‘I Inherited a Mess,’ Trump Says, Defending His Performance
articles.snippet: In a raw news conference on Thursday, President Trump dismissed reports about contacts between his advisers and Russia and said his administration was not chaotic.
articles.abstract: In a raw news conference on Thursday, President Trump dismissed reports about contacts between his advisers and Russia and said his administration was not chaotic.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Thursday dismissed reports about his associates’ contacts with Russia last year and vigorously defended his performance in his first four weeks in office, in a contentious news conference that showcased his unconventional and unconstrained presidency.

articles.headline: E.P.A. Workers Try to Block Pruitt in Show of Defiance
articles.snippet: Employees of the Environmental Protection Agency are calling their senators to try to defeat Scott Pruitt’s confirmation to run the agency.
articles.abstract: Employees of the Environmental Protection Agency are calling their senators to try to defeat Scott Pruitt’s confirmation to run the agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Employees of the Environmental Protection Agency have been calling their senators to urge them to vote on Friday against the confirmation of Scott Pruitt, President Trump’s contentious nominee to run the agency, a remarkable display of activism and defiance that presages turbulent times ahead for the E.P.A.

articles.headline: Scheme Tied to UnitedHealth Overbilled Medicare for Years, Suit Says
articles.snippet: The Justice Department moved Thursday to join a whistle-blower suit in California that claims the insurer improperly collected vast sums by claiming people under its care were sicker than they were.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department moved Thursday to join a whistle-blower suit in California that claims the insurer improperly collected vast sums by claiming people under its care were sicker than they were.
articles.lead_paragraph: UnitedHealth Group, one of the nation’s largest health insurers, is accused in a scheme that allowed its subsidiaries and other insurers to improperly overcharge Medicare by “hundreds of millions — and likely billions — of dollars,” according to a lawsuit made public on Thursday at the Justice Department’s request.

articles.headline: A Little Birdie Told Me: Playing the Market on Trump Tweets
articles.snippet: Automated bots and armchair investors are watching the president’s Twitter feed for company mentions, but predicting what happens next can be tricky.
articles.abstract: Automated bots and armchair investors are watching the president’s Twitter feed for company mentions, but predicting what happens next can be tricky.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Analyzing Twitter for market-moving information has been a business for years. High-frequency trading firms have even built such analysis into their trading strategies.

articles.headline: Is 2-State Solution Dead? In Israel, a Debate Over What’s Next
articles.snippet: Palestinians and Israelis look to the future after President Trump seemingly overturned decades of American policy centered on the creation of a Palestinian state alongside Israel.
articles.abstract: Palestinians and Israelis look to the future after President Trump seemingly overturned decades of American policy centered on the creation of a Palestinian state alongside Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The huge billboard images appeared overnight in Tel Aviv: a menacing crowd of Palestinians making the V for victory sign and bearing a legend in Arabic, “Soon we will be the majority.”

articles.headline: 20th Century Fox Gives Real Apology for a Fake News Campaign
articles.snippet: A promotion tactic for “A Cure for Wellness,” which set up false news sites that put out articles that were widely shared, fell flat, as did the film’s projected ticket sales.
articles.abstract: A promotion tactic for “A Cure for Wellness,” which set up false news sites that put out articles that were widely shared, fell flat, as did the film’s projected ticket sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since the term fake news entered the national lexicon, the advertising world has grappled with its role in inadvertently fueling the spread online of made-up stories about controversial topics.

articles.headline: In 77 Chaotic Minutes, Trump Defends ‘Fine-Tuned Machine’
articles.snippet: In a free-for-all news conference, the president took aim at enemies old and new: journalists, judges and secret-sharing Judases.
articles.abstract: In a free-for-all news conference, the president took aim at enemies old and new: journalists, judges and secret-sharing Judases.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, smarting from a series of crises, moved his surrogates aside on Thursday and assigned the rescue of his month-old presidency to the only spokesman he’s ever really trusted — himself.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Maggie Haberman and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: Samsung Heir’s Arrest in South Korea Intensifies Calls for Cleanup
articles.snippet: South Korea grows tired of the power of its biggest companies, but critics worry that the tight links between business and politics will survive.
articles.abstract: South Korea grows tired of the power of its biggest companies, but critics worry that the tight links between business and politics will survive.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A major corporate executive sits in jail, accused of participating in a corruption scandal that could topple a country’s top leader. In most places, that image would probably fuel a campaign to clean up incestuous links between business and government.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: Kraft Heinz Offers to Buy Unilever in $143 Billion Deal
articles.snippet: Unilever said that the proposal “fundamentally undervalues” the company and that it saw “no merit, either financial or strategic” for the deal.
articles.abstract: Unilever said that the proposal “fundamentally undervalues” the company and that it saw “no merit, either financial or strategic” for the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world’s grocery carts could soon be filled with more and more products from one global colossus.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Chad Bray

articles.headline: In Trump Era, Censorship May Start in the Newsroom
articles.snippet: A misfire at a PBS station showed how Trump administration attempts to intimidate the press could work, and how those attempts could be thwarted.
articles.abstract: A misfire at a PBS station showed how Trump administration attempts to intimidate the press could work, and how those attempts could be thwarted.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is how the muzzling starts: not with a boot on your neck, but with the fear of one that runs so deep that you muzzle yourself.
